member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Activity.CancellationToken
member.summary: Returns the activity's cancellation token. Activities can monitor this to gracefully handle activity cancellation.

remarks.para: We recommend that all non-local activities that execute for relatively long periods, monitor for activity cancellation so that they can gracefully terminate including potentially calling to checkpoint the current activity state.
Cancelled activities should throw a from their entry point method rather than returning a result so that Cadence will reschedule the activity if necessary.

member.exception: Thrown for local activities.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Activity.RecordHeartbeatAsync(System.Byte[])

summary.para: Records a heartbeat with optional details to Cadence.
summary.note: IMPORTANT: Heartbeats are not supported for local activities.

member.exception: Thrown for local activity executions.

remarks.para: Long running activities need to send periodic heartbeats back to Cadence to prove that the activity is still alive. This can also be used by activities to implement checkpoints or record other details. This method sends a heartbeat with optional details encoded as a byte array.
remarks.note: The maximum allowed time period between heartbeats is specified in when activities are executed and it's also possible to enable automatic heartbeats sent by the Cadence client.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Activity.HasLastHeartbeatDetailsAsync

summary.para: Determines whether the details from the last recorded heartbeat last failed attempt exist.
summary.note: IMPORTANT: Heartbeats are not supported for local activities.

member.returns: The details from the last heartbeat or null.
member.exception: Thrown for local activity executions.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Activity.GetLastHeartbeatDetailsAsync

summary.para: Returns the details from the last recorded heartbeat last failed attempt at running the activity.
summary.note: IMPORTANT: Heartbeats are not supported for local activities.

member.returns: The details from the last heartbeat or null.
member.exception: Thrown for local activity executions.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Activity.DoNotCompleteOnReturn
member.summary: This method may be called within the activity entry point to indicate that the activity will be completed externally.

remarks.note: This method is not supported for local activities.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Activity.HeartbeatAsync(System.Func{System.Byte[]},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Used to record heartbeats at a specific interval.
member.param: Optionally specifies a function that returns the heartbeat details.
Optionally specifies the interval between heartbeats. This defaults to 1/2 of activity's heartbeat timeout.
member.returns: true if a heartbeat was recorded.

remarks.para: This is a convienence method that can be used to make it easy to restrict how often activity heartbeats are actually recorded. The activity can call this as often as it likes but the method schedules heartbeat times and only transmits a heartbeat when this time has been reached.

By default, the method records heartbeats at 1/2 the activity's heartbeat timeout, but this can be customized via the parameter. No heartbeat details will be recorded by default, but you can customize this by passing a .
remarks.note: Any passed will only be called when a heartbeat is scheduled.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityMethodAttribute.Name
member.summary: Specifies the name to be used to identify a specific activity method. This is optional for activity interfaces that have only one method but is required for interfaces with multiple entry points.

remarks.para: When specified, this name will be combined with the activity type name when registering and executing an activity via the method. This will look like:
remarks.code: ACTIVITY_TYPENAME::METHODNAME
remarks.para: where ACTIVITY_TYPENAME is either the activity interface's fully qualified name or the name specified by and METHOD_NAME is from . This is the same convention implemented by the Java client.

Sometimes it's useful to be able to specify a workflow type name that doesn't follow the convention above, for example to interoperate with workflows written in another language.. You can do this by setting to the required workflow type name and then setting =true.

summary.para: Optionally indicates that holds the fully qualified type name for the workflow and that the .NET client will not add a prefix to when registering the workflow.
This is useful when interoperating with workflows written in another language by providing a way to specify a specific workflow type name.
summary.note: cannot be null or empty when this is true.

summary.para: Optionally specifies the maximum time can wait between recording a heartbeat before Cadence will consider the activity to have timed out.

Optionally specifies the maximum total time allowed for the activity to complete from the time it is scheduled. This includes the time the activity is waiting to start executing on the worker, the time it takes for the activity to execute on the worker, as well as any time scheduling and performing retries.
Optionally specifies the maximum time the activity may remain in the task list before being assigned to a worker.
Optionally specifies the maximum execution time for an individual workflow task once it has been assigned to a worker.
Optionally specifies the target task list.
Optionally specifies the target domain.

member.summary: Optionally specifies the end-to-end timeout for the activity. The default value uses the sum of and .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityOptions.ScheduleToStartTimeout
member.summary: Specifies the maximum time the activity be queued, waiting to be scheduled on a worker. This defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityOptions.StartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: Specifies the maximum time the activity may take to run. This defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityOptions.HeartbeatTimeout
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum time the activity has to send a heartbeat back to Cadence. This defaults to which indicates that no heartbeating is required.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityOptions.WaitForCancellation
member.summary: Optionally specifies that the cancelled activities won't be considered to be finished until they actually complete. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ActivityOptions.RetryOptions
member.summary: Optionally specifies the activity retry policy. The default value is null which indicates that there will be no retry attempts.

remarks.para: When is specified and it is larger than the activity's , then the will override activity's . This is to avoid retrying on error which only happen when worker is not picking up the task within the timeout.

Retrying does not make sense as it just mark the task as failed and create a new task and put back in the queue waiting worker to pick again. Cadence server also make sure the will not be larger than the workflow's timeout. Same apply to .

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient
member.summary: Implements a client that will be connected to a Cadence cluster and be used to create and manage workflows.

remarks.para: To get started with Cadence, you'll need to deploy a Cadence cluster with one or more nodes and the establish a connection to the cluster from your workflow/activity implementations and management tools. This is pretty easy to do.
First, you'll need to know the URI of at least one of the Cadence cluster nodes. Cadence listens on port 79133 by default so you cluster URIs will typically look like: http://CADENCE-NODE:7933.
remarks.note: For production clusters with multiple Cadence nodes, you should specify multiple URIs when connecting just in case the one of the nodes may be offline for some reason.
remarks.para: To establish a connection, you'll construct a and add your node URIs to the list and then call the static method to obtain a connected . You'll use this for registering workflows and activities types as well as the workers that indicate that workflows and activities can be executed in the current process.
remarks.note: IMPORTANT: The current .NET Cadence client release supports having only one client open at a time. A will be thrown when attempting to connect a second client. This restriction may be relaxed for future releases.
remarks.para: You'll implement your workflows and activities by implementing classes that derive from and and then registering these types with Cadence. Then you'll start workflow or activity workers so that Cadence will begin scheduling operations for execution by your code. Workflows and activities are registered using the fully qualified names of the derived and types by defaut, but you can customize this if desired.

Cadence supports the concept of domains and task lists. Domains and task lists are used to organize workflows and activities. Workflows and activities essentially reside in a registered domain, which is essentially just a namespace specified by a string. The combination of a domain along with a workflow or activity type name must be unique within a Cadence cluster. Once you have a connected , you can create and manage Cadence domains via methods like , , and . Domains can be used provide isolated areas for different teams and/or different environments (e.g. production, staging, and test). We discuss task lists in detail further below.

Cadence workers are started to indicate that the current process can execute workflows and activities from a Cadence domain, and optionally a task list (discussed further below). You'll call to indicate that Cadence can begin scheduling workflow and activity executions from the current client.

Workflows are implemented by defining an interface describing the workflow methods and then writing a class the implements your interface and also inherits . Your workflow interface must define at least one entry point method tagged by and may optionally include signal and query methods tagged by and .

Activities are implemented in the same way by defining an activity interface and then writing a class that implements this interface. and inherits . Your activity interface must define at least one entry point method.

After establishing a connection ot a Cadence cluster, you'll need to call and/or to register your workflow and activity implementations with Cadence. These calls combined with the workers described above determine which workflows and activities may be scheduled on the current client/process.

For situations where you have a lot of workflow and activity classes, it can become cumbersome to register each implementation class individually (generally because you forget to register new classes after they've been implemented). To assist with this, you can also tag your workflow and activity classes with or with or set to true and then call and/or to scan an assembly and automatically register the tagged implementation classes it finds.

note.para: The .NET client uses a simple huristic to try to ensure that the default workflow and activity type names applied when the and properties are not set for the interface and implementation classes. If the interface name starts with an "I", the "I" will be stripped out before generating the fully qualified type name. This handles the common C# convention where interface names started with an "I" and the implementing class uses the same name as the interface, but without the "I".
If this huristic doesn't work, you'll need to explicitly specify the same type name in the or tagging your interface and class definitions.

remarks.para: Next you'll need to start workflow and/or activity workers. These indicate to Cadence that the current process implements specific workflow and activity types. You'll call . You can customize the Cadence domain and task list the worker will listen on as well as whether activities, workflows, or both are to be processed.

You'll generally create stub classes to start and manage workflows and activities. These come in various flavors with the most important being typed and untyped stubs. Typed stubs are nice because they implement your workflow or activity interface so that the C# compiler can provide compile-time type checking. Untyped stubs provide a way to interact with workflows and activities written on other languages or for which you don't have source code.
You can create typed external workflow stubs via and .
Workflows can use their property to create child workflow as well as activity stubs.

Task lists are used by Cadence to identify the set of workflows and activities that are implemented by workers. For example, if you deploy a program called payments.exe that implements payment related workflows and activities like validate, debit, credit,... you could register these and then start a worker using tasklist=payments.

You'll need to provide the correct task list when executing a workflow or normal (non-local) activity. Cadence will schedule the workflow or activity on one of the workers that was started with the specified task list. The most convienent way to specify the task list is to tag your workflow and activity interfaces with [WorkflowInterface(TaskList = "payments")] and [ActivityInterface(TaskList = "payments")] attributes, specifying the target task list.

You may also specify a custom task list in the workflow and activity options used when executing a workflow or activity. A task list specified in one of these options takes precedence over the task list specified in an attribute.
remarks.note: The .NET client will complain if a task list is not specified in either an interface attribute or the options.

note.para: IMPORTANT: You need to take care to ensure that the task lists you use for your workers uniquely identify the set of workflows and activities registered for the workers. For example, if you start two workers, worker-a and worker-b using the same task list, but worker-a registers the foo workflow and worker-b registers the bar activity, you're going run into trouble.

The problem is that Cadence assumes that both workers implement the same workflows, both foo and bar in this case. Say you start a foo workflow. Cadence will select one of worker-a or worker-b to run the workflow. If Cadence happens to select worker-a everything will work as expected because foo is registered there. If Cadence selects worker-b the initial execution will fail because foo is not registered there. Cadence handles this a decision task failure and will attempt to reschedule the workflow on another worker (hopefully worker-a this time).

Cadence fault tolerance will probably end up being able to handle this sort misconfiguration, but at the cost of additional delays as well as unnecessary communication overhead to workers that will never be able to execute unregistered workflows and activities.

So the moral of this store is carefully choose your task lists to match the set of workflows and activities implemented by your application. One common approach is to name the task list after the service or application that implements the workflow anbd activities.

Activity and workflow stubs are generated and compiled on demand by default. This takes about 500ms for each stub. This generally works fine but may cause decision task timeouts for workflows that call a lot of different child workflows or activities.

The default workflow decision task timeout is 10 seconds, so a workflow that creates 22 stubs when its first called will have a decent chance of timing out due to the 500ms * 22 = 11 seconds it will take for the .NET client generate and build the backing classes.
note.note: This is only an issue the first time a stub classes are built, so it'll be very likely that the workflow will proceed the second time it's invoked on the same worker because the generated stub classes are cached.
note.para: You can proactively address this by prebuilding stub classes before starting any workers by calling , , and/or . After doing this, the specified stubs will already be generated and compiled when the worker starts and begins invoking workflows and activities.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.StartWorkerAsync(System.String,Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Signals Cadence that the application is capable of executing workflows and/or activities for a specific domain and task list.
member.param: Specifies the task list implemented by the worker. This must not be empty.
member.exception: Thrown if is null or empty.
Thrown when an attempt is made to recreate a worker with the same properties on a given client. See the note in the remarks.

remarks.note: for more information on task lists.
remarks.para: Your workflow application will need to call this method so that Cadence will know that it can schedule activities to run within the current process. You'll need to specify the target Cadence domain and task list.
You may also specify an optional parameter as well as customize the name used to register the activity, which defaults to the fully qualified name of the activity type.

This method returns a which implements . It's a best practice to call just before the a worker process terminates, but this is optional. Advanced worker implementation that need to change their configuration over time can also call to stop workers for specific domains and task lists.
remarks.note: The Cadence GOLANG client does not appear to support starting a worker with a given set of parameters, stopping that workflow, and then restarting another worker with the same parameters on the same client. This method detects this situation and throws an when a restart is attempted.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.NewUntypedWorkflowStub(System.String,Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions)
member.summary: Creates an untyped stub that can be used to start a single workflow execution.

remarks.para: Unlike activity stubs, a workflow stub may only be used to launch a single workflow. You'll need to create a new stub for each workflow you wish to invoke and then the first method called on a workflow stub must be the one of the methods tagged by .

note.para: .NET and Java workflows can implement multiple workflow methods using attributes and annotations to assign unique names to each. Each workflow method is actually registered with Cadence as a distinct workflow type. Workflow methods with a blank or null name will simply be registered using the workflow type name.
Workflow methods with a name will be registered using a combination of the workflow type name and the method name, using "::" as the separator, like:
GOLANG doesn't support the concept of workflow methods. GOLANG workflows are just given a simple name which you'll pass here as to make cross platform calls.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.NewWorkflowStub``1(Neon.Cadence.WorkflowExecution,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a typed workflow stub connected to a known workflow execution using a . This can be used to signal and query the workflow via the type-safe interface methods.
member.param: Optionally specifies the domain where the target workflow is running. This will be required when default domain for the client isn't specified or when the the target execution is running in a different domain.
member.returns: The dynamically generated stub that implements the workflow methods defined by .
member.remarks: Unlike activity stubs, a workflow stub may only be used to launch a single workflow. You'll need to create a new stub for each workflow you wish to invoke and then the first method called on a workflow stub must be the one of the methods tagged by .

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.NewWorkflowStub(System.String,Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions)
member.summary: Creates an untyped workflow stub to be used for launching a workflow.

remarks.para: Unlike activity stubs, a workflow stub may only be used to launch a single workflow. You'll need to create a new stub for each workflow you wish to invoke and then the first method called on a workflow stub must be the one of the methods tagged by .

note.para: .NET and Java workflows can implement multiple workflow methods using attributes and annotations to assign unique names to each. Each workflow method is actually registered with Cadence as a distinct workflow type. Workflow methods with a blank or null name will simply be registered using the workflow type name.
Workflow methods with a name will be registered using a combination of the workflow type name and the method name, using "::" as the separator, like:
GOLANG doesn't support the concept of workflow methods. GOLANG workflows are just given a simple name which you'll pass here as to make cross platform calls.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.NewWorkflowStub``1(Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a typed workflow stub that can be used to start as well as query and signal the workflow via the type-safe interface methods.
member.param: Optionally specifies the workflow type name by overriding the fully qualified type name or the name specified by a .
member.returns: The dynamically generated stub that implements the workflow methods defined by .

remarks.para: Unlike activity stubs, a workflow stub may only be used to launch a single workflow. You'll need to create a new stub for each workflow you wish to invoke and then the first method called on a workflow stub must be the one of the methods tagged by .

note.para: .NET and Java workflows can implement multiple workflow methods using attributes and annotations to assign unique names to each. Each workflow method is actually registered with Cadence as a distinct workflow type. Workflow methods with a blank or null name will simply be registered using the workflow type name.
Workflow methods with a name will be registered using a combination of the workflow type name and the method name, using "::" as the separator, like:
GOLANG doesn't support the concept of workflow methods. GOLANG workflows are just given a simple name which you'll pass here as to make cross platform calls.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceClient.SyncSignalWorkflowAsync(Neon.Cadence.WorkflowExecution,System.String,System.String,System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary: Transmits a signal to a running external workflow and then polls the completion by querying the workflow to wait for the signal to be received and processed by the workflow. This overload does not return a result. This low-level method accepts a byte array with the already encoded parameters.
member.param: The globally unique signal transaction ID.
Specifies the as a single item array and encoded as a byte array.
member.returns: The encoded signal results or null for signals that don't return a result.
member.exception: Thrown if the target synchronous signal doesn't exist or the workflow is already closed.
Thrown for internal Cadence problems.
Thrown if the operation timed out while waiting for a reply.

remarks.para: must include an internal encoded as the only argument. This first includes the information required by the worker to route to the user's signal, the globally unique transaction ID that the worker will use to track the signal execution state and the client will use to poll for that state. This also includes the encoded user arguments being passed to the signal.
remarks.note: The value passed as must match that in encoded as the encoded in .

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.CadenceHelper.ConvertArg(System.Type,System.Object)

summary.para: Used to convert an argument value being passed to a workflow or activity from its current type to the target parameter type. For example, if an int argument is being passed to a double parameter, this method will convert the int to a double and return the double.
This mimics the behavior of the C# complier which which will also perform these implicit conversions so the workflow developer won't have to do this explicitly (which would be really annoying).

member.param: The parameter type we'll be casting to.

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.ProxyMessage
member.summary: The base class for all messages transferred between the .NET Cadence client and the cadence-proxy.

remarks.para: This class is designed to be a very simple and flexible way of communicating operations and status between the Cadence client and proxy. The specific message type is identified via the property (one of the values. The dictionary will be used to pass named values. Binary attachments may be passed using the property, a list of binary arrays.

This is serialized to bytes using a simple structure consisting of 32-bit integers, UTF-8 encoded strings, and raw bytes with all integers encoded using little-endian byte ordering. Strings are encoded as a 32-bit byte length, followed by that many UTF-8 encoded string bytes. A ZERO byte length indicates an empty string and a length of -1 indicates a NULL string. Encoded strings will look like:
A full encoded message will look like:

The message starts out with the 32-bit message type followed by the number of properties to follow. Each argument consists of an encoded string for the argument name followed by an encoded string for the value.

After the properties will be a 32-bit integer specifying the number of binary attachment with each encoded as its length in bytes followed by that actual attachment bytes. An attachment with length set to -1 will be considered to be NULL.

Proxy messages will be passed between the Cadence client and proxy via PUT requests using the application/x-neon-cadence-proxy content-type. Note that request responses in both directions never include any content.
Note that more complex message property may be passed as JSON strings that can be serialized and deserialized via the and helper methods.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.ProxyMessage.GetJsonProperty``1(Neon.Cadence.Internal.PropertyNameUtf8)
member.summary: Helper method for retrieving a complex property serialized as a JSON string.
member.returns: The parsed value if the property exists or null.

note.para: IMPORTANT: Be very careful when referencing properties that use this method because the behavior will probably be unexepected. You should:

list.item: When you need to access multiple subfields of the property value, dereference the property once, save the value to a variable and then use the variable to access the subproperty. Not doing this will result in the JSON being parsed again for each property reference.

Dereferencing the property and changing a subproperty value won't actually persist the change back to the underlying property. You'll need to dereference the property to a variable, change the subproperty, and then use to persist the change.

note.para: These restrictions are a bit odd but we're not actually expecting to be doing any of these things within the cadence-client code.

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options used for executing an activity.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.TaskList
member.summary: TaskList that the activity needs to be scheduled on. optional: The default task list with the same name as the workflow task list.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.ScheduleToCloseTimeout
member.summary: ScheduleToCloseTimeout - The end to end timeout for the activity needed. The zero value of this uses default value. Optional: The default value is the sum of ScheduleToStartTimeout and StartToCloseTimeout

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.ScheduleToStartTimeout
member.summary: ScheduleToStartTimeout - The queue timeout before the activity starts executed. Mandatory: No default.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.StartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: StartToCloseTimeout - The timeout from the start of execution to end of it. Mandatory: No default.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.HeartbeatTimeout
member.summary: HeartbeatTimeout - The periodic timeout while the activity is in execution. This is the max interval the server needs to hear at-least one ping from the activity. Optional: Default zero, means no heart beating is needed.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.WaitForCancellation
member.summary: WaitForCancellation - Whether to wait for cancelled activity to be completed( activity can be failed, completed, cancel accepted) Optional: default false

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.ActivityID
member.summary: ActivityID - Business level activity ID, this is not needed for most of the cases if you have to specify this then talk to cadence team. This is something will be done in future. Optional: default empty string

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalActivityOptions.RetryPolicy
member.summary: RetryPolicy specify how to retry activity if error happens. When RetryPolicy.ExpirationInterval is specified and it is larger than the activity's ScheduleToStartTimeout, then the ExpirationInterval will override activity's ScheduleToStartTimeout. This is to avoid retrying on ScheduleToStartTimeout error which only happen when worker is not picking up the task within the timeout. Retrying ScheduleToStartTimeout does not make sense as it just mark the task as failed and create a new task and put back in the queue waiting worker to pick again. Cadence server also make sure the ScheduleToStartTimeout will not be larger than the workflow's timeout. Same apply to ScheduleToCloseTimeout. See more details about RetryPolicy on the doc for RetryPolicy. Optional: default is no retry

summary.para: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Specifies child workflow execution options. This maps closely to this Cadence GOLANG structure:
https://godoc.org/go.uber.org/cadence/internal#ChildWorkflowOptions

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.Domain
member.summary: Domain of the child workflow. Optional: the current workflow (parent)'s domain will be used if this is not provided.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.WorkflowID
member.summary: WorkflowID of the child workflow to be scheduled. Optional: an auto generated workflowID will be used if this is not provided. ///

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.TaskList
member.summary: TaskList that the child workflow needs to be scheduled on. Optional: the parent workflow task list will be used if this is not provided.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.ExecutionStartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: ExecutionStartToCloseTimeout - The end to end timeout for the child workflow execution. Mandatory: no default

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.TaskStartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: TaskStartToCloseTimeout - The decision task timeout for the child workflow. Optional: default is 10s if this is not provided (or if 0 is provided).

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.ChildClosePolicy
member.summary: ChildClosePolicy defines the behavior of child workflow when parent workflow is terminated. Optional: default to use ParentClosePolicy.RequestCancel. We currently only support this policy.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.WaitForCancellation
member.summary: WaitForCancellation - Whether to wait for cancelled child workflow to be ended (child workflow can be ended as: completed/failed/timedout/terminated/canceled) Optional: default false

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.WorkflowIdReusePolicy
member.summary: WorkflowIDReusePolicy - Whether server allow reuse of workflow ID, can be useful for dedup logic if set to WorkflowIdReusePolicyRejectDuplicate Optional: defaulted to WorkflowIdReusePolicyAllowDuplicate.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalChildWorkflowOptions.RetryPolicy
member.summary: RetryPolicy - Optional retry policy for workflow. If a retry policy is specified, in case of workflow failure server will start new workflow execution if needed based on the retry policy.

summary.para: CronSchedule - Optional cron schedule for workflow. If a cron schedule is specified, the workflow will run as a CRON workflow based on the schedule. The scheduling will be based on UTC time. Schedule for next execution only happen after the current execution is completed/failed/timeout. If a RetryPolicy is also supplied, and the workflow failed or timeout, the workflow will be retried based on the retry policy. While the workflow is retrying, it won't schedule its next execution. If next schedule is due while workflow is running (or retrying), then it will skip that schedule. Cron workflow will not stop until it is terminated or cancelled (by returning cadence.CanceledError). The cron spec is as following:
summary.code:
minute (0 - 59) hour (0 - 23) day of the month (1 - 31) month (1 - 12) day of the week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
* * * * *

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalParentClosePolicy
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Enumerates the possible child workflow behaviors when the parent workflow is closed.

member.name: F:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalParentClosePolicy.TERMINATE
member.summary: All open child workflows will be terminated when parent workflow is terminated.

member.name: F:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalParentClosePolicy.REQUEST_CANCEL
member.summary: Cancel requests will be sent to all open child workflows to all open child workflows when parent workflow is closed. This is the default policy.

member.name: F:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalParentClosePolicy.ABANDON
member.summary: Child workflow execution will continue unaffected when parent workflow is closed.

summary.para: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Used to serialize standard Neon instances into a form compatible with the Cadence GOLANG client. This class maps to the Cadence GOLANG client structure:
https://godoc.org/go.uber.org/cadence/internal#RetryPolicy

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.#ctor(Neon.Retry.LinearRetryPolicy)
member.summary: Constructs an instance from a .

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.#ctor(Neon.Retry.ExponentialRetryPolicy)
member.summary: Constructs an instance from a ,

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.InitialInterval
member.summary: Backoff interval for the first retry. If coefficient is 1.0 then it is used for all retries. Required, no default value.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.BackoffCoefficient
member.summary: Coefficient used to calculate the next retry backoff interval. The next retry interval is previous interval multiplied by this coefficient. Must be 1 or larger. Default is 2.0.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.MaximumInterval
member.summary: Specifies the maximim retry interval. Retries intervals will start at and then be multiplied by for each retry attempt until the interval reaches or exceeds , at which point point each retry will use for all subsequent attempts.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.ExpirationInterval
member.summary: Maximum time to retry. Either or is required. Retries will stop when this is exceeded even if maximum retries is not been reached.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalRetryPolicy.MaximumAttempts
member.summary: Maximum number of attempts. When exceeded the retries stop. If not set or set to 0, it means unlimited, and the policy will rely on to decide when to stop retrying. Either or "/> is required.

summary.para: Specifies Cadence errors that should not be retried. This is optional. Cadence server will stop retrying if error reason matches this list.

list.item: Timeout errors: cadenceInternal:Timeout TIMEOUT_TYPE, where TIMEOUT_TYPE can be be START_TO_CLOSE or HEARTBEAT.

summary.note: Cancellation is not a failure, so it won't be retried.

summary.para: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Specifies workflow execution options. This maps pretty closely to this Cadence GOLANG structure:
https://godoc.org/go.uber.org/cadence/internal#StartWorkflowOptions

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.ID
member.summary: ID - The business identifier of the workflow execution. Optional: defaulted to a uuid.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.TaskList
member.summary: TaskList - The decisions of the workflow are scheduled on this queue. This is also the default task list on which activities are scheduled. The workflow author can choose to override this using activity options. Mandatory: No default.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.ExecutionStartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: ExecutionStartToCloseTimeout - The timeout for duration of workflow execution (expressed in nanoseconds). Mandatory: No default.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.DecisionTaskStartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: DecisionTaskStartToCloseTimeout - The timeout for processing decision task from the time the worker pulled this task. If a decision task is lost, it is retried after this timeout. Expressed as nanoseconds. Optional: defaulted to 10 secs.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.WorkflowIdReusePolicy
member.summary: WorkflowIDReusePolicy - Whether server allow reuse of workflow ID, can be useful for dedup logic if set to WorkflowIdReusePolicyRejectDuplicate. Optional: defaulted to WorkflowIdReusePolicyAllowDuplicate.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalStartWorkflowOptions.RetryPolicy
member.summary: RetryPolicy - Optional retry policy for workflow. If a retry policy is specified, in case of workflow failure server will start new workflow execution if needed based on the retry policy.

summary.para: CronSchedule - Optional cron schedule for workflow. If a cron schedule is specified, the workflow will execution as a CRON workflow based on the schedule. The scheduling will be based on UTC time. Schedule for next execution only happen after the current execution is completed/failed/timeout. If a RetryPolicy is also supplied, and the workflow failed or timeout, the workflow will be retried based on the retry policy. While the workflow is retrying, it won't schedule its next execution. If next schedule is due while workflow is running (or retrying), then it will skip that schedule. Cron workflow will not stop until it is terminated or cancelled (by returning cadence.CanceledError). The cron spec is as following:
summary.code:
minute (0 - 59) hour (0 - 23) day of the month (1 - 31) month (1 - 12) day of the week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
* * * * *

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Specifies the options Cadence will use when assigning workflow and activity executions to a user's worker service. This maps fairly closely to the Cadence GOLANG WorkerOptions, but we removed a few fields that don't make sense to serialize. See the remarks for more information.

item.description: I don't believe we'll really need to specify this on a per-workflow basis.
We're not going to support custom workflow loggers.
I believe the cadence-proxy can a common context for all workflow executions.
This is not required because cadence-proxy deals only with raw byte arrays.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentActivityExecutionSize
member.summary: Specifies the maximum concurrent activity executions this worker can have. The zero value of this uses the default value of 1K.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.WorkerActivitiesPerSecond
member.summary: Specifies the rate limiting on number of activities that can be executed per second per worker. This defaults to 100K when the value is zero.
member.remarks: This can be used to limit resources used by the worker. Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentLocalActivityExecutionSize
member.summary: Specifies the maximum concurrent local activity executions this worker can have. This defaults to 1K when the value is zero.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.WorkerLocalActivitiesPerSecond
member.summary: Specifies the rate limiting on number of local activities that can be executed per second per worker. This can be used to limit resources used by the worker. This defaults to 100K when the value is zero.
member.remarks: This can be used to limit resources used by the worker. Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your local activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.TaskListActivitiesPerSecond
member.summary: Specifies rate limiting on number of activities that can be executed per second. This defaults to 100K when the value is zero.
member.remarks: This is managed by the server and controls activities per second for your entire task list whereas WorkerActivityTasksPerSecond controls activities only per worker. Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentDecisionTaskExecutionSize
member.summary: Specifies the maximum concurrent decision task executions this worker can have. This defaults to 1K when the value is zero.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.WorkerDecisionTasksPerSecond
member.summary: Specifies the rate limiting on number of decision tasks that can be executed per second per worker. This can be used to limit resources used by the worker. The zero value of this uses the default value. Default: 100k

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.AutoHeartBeat
member.summary: Enables auto heart-beating for activities. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.Identity
member.summary: Specifies an identity that will be used to track this host for debugging. This will be included in the Cadence woirkflow history. This defaults to a string including the current hostname, groupName and process ID.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.EnableLoggingInReplay
member.summary: Optionally enables logging during workflow replay. This defaults to false.
member.remarks: By default, the workflow logger will not log events while workflows are replaying to avoid duplicate logs. Enabling this is generally useful only for debugging purposes.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.DisableWorkflowWorker
member.summary: Optionally prevents the worker from executing workflows. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.DisableActivityWorker
member.summary: Optionally prevents the worker from executing activities. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.DisableStickyExecution
member.summary: Optionally disables sticky execution. This defaults to false.
member.remarks: Sticky Execution is to run the decision tasks for one workflow execution on same worker host. This is an optimization for workflow execution. When sticky execution is enabled, worker keeps the workflow state in memory. New decision task contains the new history events will be dispatched to the same worker. If this worker crashes, the sticky decision task will timeout after StickyScheduleToStartTimeout, and cadence server will clear the stickiness for that workflow execution and automatically reschedule a new decision task that is available for any worker to pick up and resume the progress.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.StickyScheduleToStartTimeout
member.summary: Optionally disables the sticky schedule to start timeout. This defaults to 5 seconds.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.NonDeterministicWorkflowPolicy
member.summary: Configures how decision worker deals with non-deterministic history events. This defaults to which logs an error but does not fail the workflow.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.InternalWorkerOptions.WorkerStopTimeout
member.summary: Specifies the maximum time the client will wait for the worker to shutdown gracefully before it will be forcefully terminated.

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalCall
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Holds information necessary to implement synchronous signals. This is used internally for transmitting synchronous signals to workflows.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalCall.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The encoded user arguments being passed to the signal.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalCall.TargetSignal
member.summary: Identifies the signal method targeted by the user. We need this because the the signal will be sent to and the internal handler will need this to identify the actual user single method to be called.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalCall.SignalId
member.summary: Specifies a globally unique ID for the signal request operation. The target worker will manage the current state of the signal request and the client will use this to poll the worker for the current state.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalCall.UserArgs
member.summary: The encoded user arguments being passed to the signal.

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus
member.summary: Holds the status of a synchronous signal execution.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus.Args
member.summary: Returns the dictionary of signal method arguments keyed by parameter name.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus.Completed
member.summary: Returns true if the workflow has finished executing the signal and that the result is available (for non-void signals).

summary.para: Returns potential error information when =true. This will return null if the signal completed without error or else an error string describing the exception thrown by the signal method.
summary.note: This string must be formatted by .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus.Result
member.summary: Returns the encoded result for signals that return results. This will be null for signals that don't return a result.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus.Acknowledged
member.summary: Returns true after the workflow has returned the result of the completed signal operation to a polling query. This is used internally to delay returning from the workflow while there remain outstanding synchronous signals that have not been answered.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.Internal.SyncSignalStatus.AcknowledgeTimeUtc
member.summary: Returns the time (UTC) when the signal was acknowledged.

summary.para: proxy --> client: This is a special reply message sent for workflow operations that are implemented in GOLANG as futures and may be executed in parallel. cadence-proxy will send this message after it has submitted the operation to Cadence but before the future actually completes. The .NET client uses this reply as an indication that another Cadence operation may be started.
summary.note: This message does not have a corresponding request message (which is why the name doesn't end with "Reply".

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings
member.summary: Cadence client settings.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.summary: Constructs an instance with server URIs.
member.param: Specifies one or more server URIs.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.Servers
member.summary: One or more Cadence server URIs.
member.remarks: You must specify the URI for at least one operating Cadence node. The Cadence client will use this to discover the remaining nodes. It is a best practice to specify multiple nodes in a clustered environment to avoid initial connection problems if any single node is down.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.ListenPort
member.summary: Optionally specifies the port where the client will listen for traffic from the associated cadence-proxy. This defaults to 0 which specifies that lets the operating system choose an unused ephermal port.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DefaultDomain
member.summary: Specifies the default Cadence domain for this client. This defaults to null.

remarks.para: Specifying a default domain can be convienent for many scenarios, especially for those where the application workflows and activities are restricted to a single domain (which is pretty common). This defaults to "default".
The default domain can be overridden for workflow interfaces via or for specific interface methods via .

summary.para: Optionally create the if it doesn't already exist. This defaults to false.
summary.note: Enabling this can be handy for unit testing where you'll likely be starting off with a virgin Cadence server when the test start. We don't recommend enabling this for production services. For production, you should explicitly create your domains with suitable setttings such has how long workflow histories are to be retained.
If the default domain doesn't exist when =true when a connection is established, it will be initialized to retain workflow histories for up to 7 days.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DefaultTaskList
member.summary: Specifies the default Cadence task list for this client. This defaults to null.

remarks.para: Specifying a default task list can be convienent for many scenarios, especially for those where the application workflows and activities are restricted to a single task list.
The default task list can be overridden for workflow interfaces via or for specific interface methods via .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.ClientTimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum time the client should wait for synchronous operations to complete. This defaults to 10 seconds.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.ClientTimeout
member.summary: Returns as a .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.ClientIdentity
member.summary: Optionally identifies the client application establishing the connection so that Cadence may include this in its logs and metrics. This defaults to "unknown".

summary.para: The Cadence cluster security token. This defaults to null.
summary.note: This is not currently supported by the .NET Cadence client and should be left alone for now.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.ProxyTimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum time to allow the cadence-proxy to indicate that it has received a proxy request message by returning an OK response. The proxy will be considered to be unhealthy when this happens. This defaults to 5 seconds.

member.summary: EXPERIMENTAL: Specifies the maximum seconds that a workflow will be kept alive after the workflow method returns to handle any oustanding synchronous signal queries. This defaults to 30.0 seconds.

member.summary: Returns as a .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.MaxWorkflowWaitUntilRunning
member.summary: Returns as a .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.BinaryFolder
member.summary: Optionally specifies the folder where the embedded cadence-proxy binary will be written before starting it. This defaults to null which specifies that the binary will be written to the same folder where the Neon.Cadence assembly resides. This folder may not be writable by the current user so this allows you to specify an alternative folder.

summary.para: Optionally specifies the path to the cadence-proxy executable file. This file must already be present on disk when a connection is established and the appropriate execute permissions must be set for Linux and OS/X. This property takes presidence over when set.
This is useful for situations where the executable must be pre-provisioned for security. One example is deploying Cadence workers to a Docker container with a read-only file system.
summary.note: You can use the method to extract the Windows, Linux, and OS/X builds of the cadence-proxy executable from the Neon.Cadence assembly.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.LogLevel
member.summary: Optionally specifies the logging level for the associated cadence-proxy. This defaults to which will be appropriate for most production situations. You may wish to set this to or while debugging.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.LogCadence
member.summary: Optionally specifies that messages from the embedded GOLANG Cadence client will be included in the log output. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.LogCadenceProxy
member.summary: Optionally specifies that messages from the internal cadence-proxy code that bridges between .NET and the embedded GOLANG Cadence client will be included in the log output. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.LogDuringReplay
member.summary: Optionally enable workflow logging while the workflow is being replayed from history. This should generally be enabled only while debugging. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.Debug
member.summary: Optionally specifies that the connection should run in DEBUG mode. This currently launches the cadence-proxy with a command window (on Windows only) to make it easy to see any output it generates and also has cadence-proxy. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugPrelaunched
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally indicates that the cadence-proxy will already be running for debugging purposes. When this is true, the cadence-client be hardcoded to listen on 127.0.0.1:5001 and the cadence-proxy will be assumed to be listening on 127.0.0.1:5000. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugDisableHeartbeats
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally disable health heartbeats. This can be useful while debugging the client but should never be set for production. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugDisableHandshakes
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally indicates that the cadence-client will not perform the / and / handshakes with the cadence-proxy for debugging purposes. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugIgnoreTimeouts
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally ignore operation timeouts. This can be useful while debugging the client but should never be set for production. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugIgnoreHeartbeats
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally disables heartbeat handling by the emulated cadence-proxy for testing purposes.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.DebugHttpTimeout
member.summary: INTERNAL USE ONLY: Optionally specifies the timeout to use for HTTP requests made to the cadence-proxy. This defaults to 5 seconds.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.CadenceSettings.Clone
member.summary: Returns a copy of the current instance.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.Domain
member.summary: Optionally specifies the target domain. This defaults to the domain specified by , , or to the client's default domain as specified by (in that order of precedence).

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.WorkflowId
member.summary: Optionally specifies the workflow ID to assign to the child workflow. A UUID will be generated by default.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.TaskList
member.summary: Optionally specifies the Cadence task list where the child workflow will be scheduled. This defaults to the domain specified by or , or the parent workflow's domain, in that order of precedence.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.StartToCloseTimeout
member.summary: Specifies the maximum time the child workflow may execute from start to finish. This defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.ScheduleToStartTimeout
member.summary: Optionally specifies the default maximum time a workflow can wait between being scheduled and actually begin executing. This defaults to 24 hours.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.DecisionTaskTimeout
member.summary: Optionally specifies the decision task timeout for the child workflow. This defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.ChildPolicy
member.summary: Optionally specifies what happens to the child workflow when the parent is terminated. This defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.WaitUntilFinished
member.summary: Optionally specifies whether to wait for the child workflow to finish for any reason including being: completed, failed, timedout, terminated, or canceled.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.WorkflowIdReusePolicy
member.summary: Optionally determines how Cadence handles workflows that attempt to reuse workflow IDs. This generally defaults to but the default can be customized via the tagging the workflow entry point method or (which also defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.RetryOptions
member.summary: Optionally specifies retry options.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions.CronSchedule
member.summary: Optionally specifies a recurring schedule for the workflow. This can be set to a string specifying the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week scheduling parameters using the standard Linux CRON format described here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron

remarks.para: Cadence accepts a CRON string formatted as a single line of text with 5 parameters separated by spaces. The parameters specified the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week values:
remarks.code:
minute (0 - 59) hour (0 - 23) day of the month (1 - 31) month (1 - 12) day of the week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
* * * * *
remarks.para: Each parameter may be set to one of:

item.description: Matches any value.
Matches a specific integer value.
Matches a range of integer values (inclusive).
Matches a list of integer values.
Matches values starting at first and then succeeding incremented by step.

remarks.para: You can use this handy CRON calculator to see how this works: https://crontab.guru

summary.para: Returns the underlying stub for the child workflow. This includes all the workflow entrypoint, query and signal methods.
summary.note: The entrypoint methods won't work because the workflow will already be running but you can interact with the child workflow using any query and signal methods.

member.summary: Constructs an instance from a ,

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.RetryOptions.InitialInterval
member.summary: Specifies the backoff interval for the first retry. If coefficient is 1.0 then it is used for all retries. Required, no default value.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.RetryOptions.BackoffCoefficient
member.summary: Specifies the coefficient used to calculate the next retry backoff interval. The next retry interval is previous interval multiplied by this coefficient. This must be 1 or larger. Default is 2.0.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.RetryOptions.MaximumInterval
member.summary: Specifies the maximim retry interval. Retries intervals will start at and then be multiplied by for each retry attempt until the interval reaches or exceeds , at which point point each retry will use for all subsequent attempts.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.RetryOptions.ExpirationInterval
member.summary: Maximum time to retry. Either or is required. Retries will stop when this is exceeded even if maximum retries is not been reached.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.RetryOptions.MaximumAttempts
member.summary: Maximum number of attempts. When exceeded the retries stop. If not set or set to 0, it means unlimited, and the policy will rely on to decide when to stop retrying. Either or "/> is required.

summary.para: Specifies Cadence errors that should not trigger a retry. This is optional. Cadence server will stop retrying if error reason matches this list. Use the class methods to initialize this list as required.
summary.note: Cancellation is not a failure, so that won't be retried.

remarks.para: You can specify non-retryable error reasons directly here or use the method to append a specific reason string or to specify the error reason for an exception type.
We recommend that you use most of the time and reserve for interop situations where you need to integrate with something written in another language.
For native Cadence exceptions like , is smart enough to append the proper error reason. For other exception types, this method will use the fully qualified exception type name as the reason.

summary.para: Appends the error reason corresponding to an exception type. For built-in Cadence exceptions, this will append the apporpriate reason string and for other exception type, this will append the fully qualified exception type name.
summary.note: We generally recommend that you use by default and reserve this for situations where you need to specify a specific reason, probably for interoperating with workflows and activities written in other lanagues, etc.

summary.para: Appends the string passed to as a reason not to be retried.
summary.note: We generally recommend that you use by default and reserve this for situations where you need to specify a specific reason, probably for interoperating with workflows and activities written in other lanagues, etc.

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.SignalMethodAttribute
member.summary: Used to identify a workflow interface methods as a signal.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.SignalMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.SignalMethodAttribute.Name
member.summary: Returns the signal name.

summary.para: EXPERIMENTAL: Indicates whether the tagged signal method should be generated as a synchronous method rather than as a fire-and-forget asynchronous call, which is the Cadence default. This property defaults to false.
summary.note: Synchronous signals are considered experimental which means that this feature will probably have a limited lifespan. Cadence will introduce new update semantics at some point that will ultimately obsolete synchronous signals.

remarks.para: Normal Cadence signals are sent to workflows asynchronously. This means that the signal method being called by the application will return ragardless of whether the workflow has actually received and processed the signal or not. This is quite efficient and has the advantage of not requring the sending application to wait for a somewhat indeterminate period of time for the workflow to receive and process the signal.

Sometimes though, you calling applications really need to know that the workflow actually handled a signal before moving on. Applications may also need information back from the workflow, such as whether the workflow was able to process the signal request sucessfully. So it would be nice if workflow signals could also return a result.

The Neon Cadence client supports synchronous signals by setting this property to true. When you do this, the Cadence client allows the signal method to return a result as a as well returning just a simple . For both cases, the Cadence client will generate a signal stub that waits for the signal to be processed by the target workflow before returning.

This is an experimental feature. Cadence server doesn't currently have a synchronous way to interact with a running workflow, so the Neon Cadence client emulates this behavior using a combination of internal signals and queries. As a developer, you couild have done something like this yourself, but we felt this was going to be such a useful pattern that it was worth building into the client. This will ultimately be replaced by upcoming Cadence server features.
See the documentation site for more information: Synchronous Signals

summary.para: EXPERIMENTAL: Used to relay a received synchronous signal's arguments to the workflow logic via a allowing the workflow handle the signal by executing activities, child workflows, etc. This class also provides a way for the workflow to specify the signal reply.
This non-generic version of the class is intended for signals that return void. Use for signals that return a result.
summary.note: This synchronous signals are considered experimental which means that this feature will probably have a limited lifespan. Cadence will introduce new update semantics at some point that will ultimately obsolete synchronous signals.

remarks.para: The property returns a dictionary that is intialized with the signal arguments keyed by parameter name. Your signal method should queue this request to a workflow queue your workflow logic is listening on and then return from your signal method.

Your workflow logic will dequeue the signal request, extract the signal arguments cast them to the appropriate types, and then perform any necessary operations. Then call which indicates that signal processing is finished.
See the documentation site for more information: Synchronous Signals

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.SignalRequest.ReplyAsync
member.summary: Called by your workflow logic to indicate that processing for the synchronous signal is complete. This method also waits for a period of time before returning to help ensure that the signal result can be delivered back to the calling client before the workflow terminates.

summary.para: EXPERIMENTAL: Used to relay a received synchronous signal's arguments to the workflow logic via a allowing the workflow handle the signal by executing activities, child workflows, etc. This class also provides a way for the workflow to specify the signal reply.
This generic version of the class is intended for signals that return results. Use for signals that return void.
summary.note: This synchronous signals are considered experimental which means that this feature will probably have a limited lifespan. Cadence will introduce new update semantics at some point that will ultimately obsolete synchronous signals.

remarks.para: The property returns a dictionary that is intialized with the signal arguments keyed by parameter name. Your signal method should queue this request to a workflow queue your workflow logic is listening on and then return from the signal method. The value your return will be ignore in this case and the actual value returned to the calling client will be specified by your workflow logic via a call.

Your workflow logic will dequeue the signal request, extract the signal arguments, casting them to the appropriate types, and then perform any necessary operations before calling which indicates that signal processing is finished was well as specifying the value to be returned as the signal result.
See the documentation site for more information: Synchronous Signals

member.summary: Specifies the options Cadence will use when assigning workflow and activity executions to a user worker service.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentActivityExecutionSize
member.summary: Optionally sets set the maximum concurrent activity executions this worker can have. The zero value of this uses the default value. Defaults to 1000.

summary.para: Optionally sets the rate limiting on number of activities that can be executed per second per worker. This can be used to limit resources used by the worker.
summary.note: Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding. The zero value of this uses the default value..
summary.para: This defaults to 100,000.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentLocalActivityExecutionSize
member.summary: Optionally sets the maximum concurrent local activity executions this worker can have. The zero value of this uses the default value. This defaults to 1000.

summary.para: Optionally sets the rate limiting on number of local activities that can be executed per second per worker. This can be used to limit resources used by the worker.
summary.note: Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your local activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding. The zero value of this uses the default value.
summary.para: This defaults to 100,000.

Optionally sets the rate limiting on number of activities that can be executed per second. This is managed by the server and controls activities per second for your entire task list whereas WorkerActivityTasksPerSecond controls activities only per worker.
summary.note: Notice that the number is represented in float, so that you can set it to less than 1 if needed. For example, set the number to 0.1 means you want your activity to be executed once for every 10 seconds. This can be used to protect down stream services from flooding.
summary.para: The zero value of this uses the default value. This defaults to 100,000.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.MaxConcurrentDecisionTaskExecutionSize
member.summary: Optionally sets the maximum concurrent decision task executions this worker can have. The zero value of this uses the default value. This defaults to 100,000.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.WorkerDecisionTasksPerSecond
member.summary: Optionally stes the rate limiting on number of decision tasks that can be executed per second per worker. This can be used to limit resources used by the worker. The zero value of this uses the default value. This defaults to 1000.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.Identity
member.summary: Optionally sets an identify that can be used to track this host for debugging. This defaults to include the hostname, groupName and process ID.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.EnableLoggingInReplay
member.summary: Optionally enables logging in replay. This defaults to false.
member.remarks: In the workflow code you can use workflow.GetLogger(ctx) to write logs. By default, the logger will skip log entry during replay mode so you won't see duplicate logs. This option will enable the logging in replay mode. This is only useful for debugging purpose.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.DisableWorkflowWorker
member.summary: Optionally disable workflow processing on the worker. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.DisableActivityWorker
member.summary: Optionally disable activity processing on the worker. This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.Mode
member.summary: Returns the worker mode.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.DisableStickyExecution
member.summary: Optionally disables sticky execution. This defaults to false.
member.remarks: This is an optimization for workflow execution. When sticky execution is enabled, the worker can maintain workflow state and history making workflow replaying faster.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.StickyScheduleToStartTimeout
member.summary: Optionally sets the sticky schedule to start timeout. Defaults to 5 seconds.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkerOptions.NonDeterministicWorkflowPolicy
member.summary: Optionally sets how decision workers deals with non-deterministic history events, presumably arising from non-deterministic workflow definitions or non-backward compatible workflow definition changes. This defaults to which just logs error and does not fail the workflow.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.GetVersionAsync(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Used to implement backwards compatible changes to a workflow implementation.
member.param: Specifies the minimum supported version. You may pass (-1) which will be set as the version for workflows that haven't been versioned yet.
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.para: It is possible to upgrade workflow implementation with workflows in flight using the method. The essential requirement is that the new implementation must execute the same logic for the decision steps that have already been executed and recorded to the history fo a previous workflow to maintain workflow determinism. Subsequent unexecuted steps, are free to implement different logic.
remarks.note: Cadence attempts to detect when replaying workflow performs actions that are different from those recorded as history and will fail the workflow when this occurs.
remarks.para: Upgraded workflows will use to indicate where upgraded logic has been inserted into the workflow. You'll pass a changeId string that identifies the change being made. This can be anything you wish as long as it's not empty and is unique for each change made to the workflow. You'll also pass minSupported and maxSupported integers. minSupported specifies the minimum version of the workflow implementation that will be allowed to continue to run. Workflows start out with their version set to or (-1) and this will often be passed as minSupported such that upgraded workflow implementations will be able to take over newly scheduled workflows. maxSupported essentially specifies the current (latest) version of the workflow implementation.

When called and is not being replayed from the workflow history, the method will record the changeId and maxSupported values to the workflow history. When this is being replayed, the method will simply return the maxSupported value from the history. Let's go through an example demonstrating how this can be used. Let's say we start out with a simple two step workflow that first calls ActivityA and then calls ActivityB:

Now, let's assume that we need to replace the call to ActivityA with a call to ActivityC. If there is no chance of any instances of MyWorkflow still being in flight, you could simply redepoy the recoded workflow:

But, if instances of this workflow may be in flight you'll need to deploy a backwards compatible workflow implementation that handles workflows that have already executed ActivityA but haven't yet executed ActivityB. You can accomplish this via:

This upgraded workflow calls passing minSupported=DefaultVersion and maxSupported=1 For workflow instances that have already executed ActivityA, will return and we'll call ActivityA, which will match what was recorded in the history. For workflows that have not yet executed ActivityA, will return 1, which we'll use as the indication that we can call ActivityC.
Now, lets say we need to upgrade the workflow again and change the call for ActivityB to ActivityD, but only for workflows that have also executed ActivityC. This would look something like:

Notice that the second call passed a different change ID and also that the version range is now 1..2. The version returned will be or 1 if ActivityA and ActivityB were recorded in the history or 2 if ActivityC was called.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.MutableSideEffectAsync``1(System.String,System.Func{``0})
member.summary: Calls the specified function and then searches the workflow history to see if a value was already recorded with the specified . If no value has been recorded for the or the value returned by the function will be recorded, replacing any existing value. If the function value is the same as the history value, then nothing will be recorded.
member.param: Identifies the value in the workflow history.
member.returns: The latest value persisted to the workflow history.
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.para: This is similar to what you could do with a local activity but is a bit easier since you don't need to declare the activity and create a stub to call it and it's also more efficient because it avoids recording the same value multiple times in the history.
remarks.note: The function must return within the configured decision task timeout and should avoid throwing exceptions.
The function passed should avoid throwing exceptions. When an exception is thrown, this method will catch it and simply return the default value for .

note.para:
The .NET version of this method currently works a bit differently than the Java and GOLANG clients which will only call the function once. The .NET implementation calls the function every time
is called but it will ignore the all but the first call's result.
This is an artifact of how the .NET client is currently implemented and may change in the future. You should take care not to code your application to depend on this behavior (one way or the other).

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.SleepAsync(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Pauses the workflow for at least the specified interval.
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.note: This must be used instead of calling or to guarantee determinism when a workflow is replayed.

Cadence time interval resolution is limited to whole seconds and the duration will be rounded up to the nearest second and the workflow may resumed sometime after the requested interval depending on how busy the registered workers are and how long it takes to actually wake the workflow.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.SleepUntilUtcAsync(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Pauses the workflow until at least the specified time (UTC).
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.note: Cadence timers have a resolution of only one second at this time and due to processing delays, it's very possible that the workflow will wake several seconds later than scheduled. You should not depend on time resolutions less than around 10 seconds.
