member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.NewLocalActivityStub``2(Neon.Cadence.LocalActivityOptions)
member.summary: Creates a client stub that can be used to launch one or more local activity instances via the type-safe interface methods.
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.note: Unlike workflow stubs, a single activity stub instance can be used to launch multiple activities.
remarks.para: Activities launched by the returned stub will be executed in the current process. This is intended to easily and efficiently execute activities that will complete very quickly (usually within a few seconds). Local activities are similar to normal activities with these differences:

list.item: Local activities are always scheduled to executed within the current process.
Local activity types do not need to be registered with the worker.
Local activities must complete within the . This defaults to 10 seconds and can be set to a maximum of 60 seconds.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.NewChildWorkflowFutureStub``1(System.String,Neon.Cadence.ChildWorkflowOptions)
member.summary: Creates a specialized stub suitable for starting and running a child workflow in parallel with other workflow operations such as child workflows or activities.
member.param: Optionally identifies the target workflow method. This is the name specified in [WorkflowMethod] attribute for the workflow method or null/empty for the default workflow method.
member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.para: Sometimes workflows need to run child workflows in parallel with other child workflows or activities. Although the typed workflow stubs return a or , workflow developers are required to immediately await every call to these stubs to ensure that the workflow will execute consistently when replayed from history. This means that you must not do something like this:

The MainAsync() workflow method here creates and starts a child workflow, but it doesn't immediately await it. It then runs another child workflow in parallel and then after the second child returns, the workflow awaits the first child. This pattern is not supported by Neon.Cadence because all workflow related operations need to be immediately awaited to ensure that operations will complete in a consistent order when workflows are replayed.
remarks.note: The reason for this restriction is related to how the current Neon.Cadence implementation uses an embedded GOLANG Cadence client to actually communicate with a Cadence cluster. This may be relaxed in the future if/when we implement native support for the Cadence protocol.
remarks.para: A correct implementation would look something like this:

Here we call specifying "child" as the workflow method name. This matches the [WorkflowMethod(Name = "child")] attribute decorating the ChildAsync() workflow interface method. Then we start the child workflow by awaiting . This returns an whose method returns the workflow result. The code above calls this to retrieve the result from the first child after executing the second child in parallel.

note.para: You must take care to pass parameters that match the target method. Neon.Cadence does check these at runtime, but there is no compile-time checking.

You'll also need to cast the result to the actual type (if required). This method always returns the object type even if referenced workflow and activity methods return void. will return null in these cases.

remarks.para: Sometimes workflows need to run activities written in other languages in parallel with other child workflows or activities. Although the standard stubs return a or , workflow developers are required to immediately await every call to these stubs to ensure that the workflow will execute consistently when replayed from history. This means that you must not do something like this:

The MainAsync() workflow method here starts an activity but doesn't immediately await it. It then runs another activity in parallel and then after the second activity returns, the workflow awaits the first activity. This pattern is not supported by Neon.Cadence because all workflow related operations need to be immediately awaited to ensure that operations will complete in a consistent order when workflows are replayed.
remarks.note: The reason for this restriction is related to how the current Neon.Cadence implementation uses an embedded GOLANG Cadence client to actually communicate with a Cadence cluster. This may be relaxed in the future if/when we implement native support for the Cadence protocol.
remarks.para: A correct implementation would look something like this:

Here we call specifying "foo" as the workflow method name. This matches the [ActivityMethod(Name = "foo")] decorating the FooAsync() activity interface method. Then we start the first activity by awaiting . This returns an whose method returns the activity result. The code above calls this to retrieve the result from the first activity after executing the second activity in parallel.

note.para: You must take care to pass parameters that match the target method. Neon.Cadence does check these at runtime, but there is no compile-time checking for this scheme.

You'll also need to cast the result to the actual type (if required). This method always returns the object type even if referenced workflow and activity methods return void. will return null in these cases.

member.name: M:Neon.Cadence.Workflow.NewQueueAsync``1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new workflow safe queue. These are typically used by workflow signal methods for communicating with the workflow logic.

param.name: capacity
param.para: Specifies the maximum number items the queue may hold.

member.exception: Thrown if the associated Cadence client is disposed.
Thrown when this is called outside of a workflow entry point method.

remarks.para: You may write and read data items from the returned queue. Writes will block when the queue is full until an item has been read, freeing a slot.
remarks.note: Items will be serialized internally using the current to bytes before actually enqueuing the item. This serialized data must be less than 64KiB.
remarks.para: See for more information.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.Name
member.summary: Specifies the name to be used to identify a specific workflow method. This is optional for workflow interfaces that have only one workflow entry point method but is required for interfaces with multiple entry points.

remarks.para: When specified, this name will be combined with the workflow type name when registering and executing a workflow started via the method. This will typically look like:
remarks.code: WORKFLOW_TYPENAME::METHODNAME
remarks.para: where WORKFLOW_TYPENAME is either the workflow interface's fully qualified name or the name specified by and METHOD_NAME is from . This is the same convention implemented by the Java client.

Sometimes it's useful to be able to specify a workflow type name that doesn't follow the convention above, for example to interoperate with workflows written in another language.. You can do this by setting to the required workflow type name and then setting =true.

summary.para: Optionally indicates that holds the fully qualified type name for the workflow and that the .NET client will not add a prefix to when registering the workflow.
This is useful when interoperating with workflows written in another language by providing a way to specify a specific workflow type name.
summary.note: cannot be null or empty when this is true.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.StartToCloseTimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum workflow execution time.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.DecisionTaskTimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum execution time for an individual workflow decision task. The maximum possible duration is 60 seconds.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.ScheduleToStartTimeoutSeconds
member.summary: Optionally specifies the maximum time a workflow can wait between being scheduled and being actually executed on a worker.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.TaskList
member.summary: Optionally specifies the target Cadence task list.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.Domain
member.summary: Optionally specifies the target Cadence domain.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.WorkflowId
member.summary: Optionally specifies the workflow ID.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.WorkflowIdReusePolicy
member.summary: Specifies the workflow ID reuse policy.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowMethodAttribute.CronSchedule
member.summary: Optionally specifies a recurring schedule for the workflow method. This can be set to a string specifying the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week scheduling parameters using the standard Linux CRON format described here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron

remarks.para: Cadence accepts a CRON string formatted as a single line of text with 5 parameters separated by spaces. The parameters specified the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week values:
remarks.code:
minute (0 - 59) hour (0 - 23) day of the month (1 - 31) month (1 - 12) day of the week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
* * * * *
remarks.para: Each parameter may be set to one of:

item.description: Matches any value.
Matches a specific integer value.
Matches a range of values to be matched (inclusive).
Matches a list of values to be matched.
Matches values starting at value1 and then those incremented by value2.

remarks.para: You can use this handy CRON calculator to see how this works: https://crontab.guru

summary.note: This overrides the optional corresponding value specified in the tagging the workflow entry point method.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions.DecisionTaskTimeout
member.summary: Optionally specifies the timeout for processing decision task from the time the worker pulled a task. If a decision task is not completed within this interval, it will be retried as specified by the retry policy. This defaults to 10 seconds when not specified. The maximum timeout is 60 seconds.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions.WorkflowIdReusePolicy
member.summary: Optionally determines how Cadence handles workflows that attempt to reuse workflow IDs. This generally defaults to but the default can be customized via the tagging the workflow entry point method or (which also defaults to .

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions.RetryOptions
member.summary: Optional retry options for the workflow.

member.name: P:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowOptions.CronSchedule
member.summary: Optionally specifies a recurring schedule for the workflow. This can be set to a string specifying the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week scheduling parameters using the standard Linux CRON format described here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron

remarks.para: Cadence accepts a CRON string formatted as a single line of text with 5 parameters separated by spaces. The parameters specified the minute, hour, day of month, month, and day of week values:
remarks.code:
minute (0 - 59) hour (0 - 23) day of the month (1 - 31) month (1 - 12) day of the week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
* * * * *
remarks.para: Each parameter may be set to one of:

item.description: Matches any value.
Matches a specific integer value.
Matches a range of values to be matched (inclusive).
Matches a list of values to be matched.
Matches values starting at value1 and then those incremented by value2.

remarks.para: You can use this handy CRON calculator to see how this works: https://crontab.guru

summary.para: Optionally specifies workflow metadata as a dictionary of named object values.
summary.note: The object values will be serialized into bytes using the the client's .

member.name: T:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowQueue`1
member.summary: Implements a workflow-safe first-in-first-out (FIFO) queue that can be used by workflow signal methods to communicate with the running workflow logic.
member.typeparam: Specifies the type of the queued items.

remarks.para: You can construct workflow queue instances in your workflows via , optionally specifying the maximum capacity of the queue. This defaults to and may not be less that 2 queued items.

Items are added to the queue via . This method will return immediately when the number of items currently in the queue is less than the capacity, otherwise the operation will block until an item has been dequeued and the queue is no longer full.
remarks.note: Serialized item sizes must be less than 64 KiB.
remarks.para: Use to read from the queue using an optional timeout.

note.para: The class is intended only for two scenarios within an executing workflow:

list.item: Workflow Entry Point: Workflow entry points have full access queues including creating, closing, reading, writing, and fetching the length.
Workflow Signal: Workflow signal methods have partial access to queues including closing, writing, and fetching the length. Signals cannot create or read from queues.

member.name: F:Neon.Cadence.WorkflowQueue`1.DefaultCapacity
member.summary: The default maximum number of items allowed in a queue.

summary.para: Returns the workflow type name.

note.para: .NET and Java workflows can implement multiple workflow method using attributes and annotations to assign unique names to each. Each workflow method is actually registered with Cadence as a distinct workflow type. Workflow methods with a blank or null name will simply be registered using the workflow type name.
Workflow methods with a name will be registered using a combination of the workflow type name and the method name, using "::" as the separator, like:
